MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Matter. - Roscommon County Hospital.

Speaker.P: The saga of Roscommon Hospital has been ongoing now for 20 years. It was an issue in the 1965 general election when a member of the then Cabinet, Deputy Brian Lenihan, and a candidate in the Roscommon constituency promised that the hospital would be upgraded. Needless to say, that promise was not kept. However, the hospital weathered all the storms in the intervening years, threats proposed by the FitzGerald Report, the Health Act, 1970, etc., etc. It commenced this financial year of 1987 in good shape. It had been much improved since Deputy Lenihan spoke about it in 1965. Its equipment was very modern; it had three consultants, a nursing staff of about 80; 137 medical/surgical beds often going to as high as 152 occupied beds. It was one of the most economic county surgical hospitals in the country. It had an annual throughput of approximately 5,000 patients and it had an excellent reputation for surgery, medical care and for treatment.

It might have felt very secure about its future at the beginning of 1987. In the general election campaign of January and February of 1987 some of the following things were said and I would like to put them on the record of the House. I am quoting from a copy of the Roscommon Herald dated 13 February, 1987: I see one heading — I am glad the Minister is here to observe this — which is “A Vote for Leyden is a Vote for the Hospital”. It goes on:
Speaking at Four Roads and his home village of Fuerty, Terry Leyden stated “a vote for Leyden” is a “vote for the hospital”.
This was during the general election campaign of 1987 and it is a direct quote. He continued:
As a parent resident in the area I know the feeling of security to have a top grade hospital in the area. As long as Leyden is elected in Roscommon the future of Roscommon hospital is ensured.
There is another headline which reads: “Vote F.F. and secure Hospital”. This is a statement attributed to Deputy Sean Doherty. I quote:

MainHeading.P: Support for any party or candidate in this election other than the Fianna Fáil candidates will be detrimental to the future of Roscommon County Hospital, Mr. Seán Doherty told supporters at rallies in Cloonfad and Elphin on Saturday night last. Mr. Doherty said Fianna Fáil had always supported services at the hospital and anything that jeopardises the return to Government of Fianna Fáil would cast serious doubts on its future. Consequently, voters who valued the services at the hospital and support their retention should not cast their votes by way of protest and still expect the hospital to survive under a party other than Fianna Fáil. He said it was the Coalition Government which allowed Mr. Barry Desmond when he was Minister to state that Roscommon County Hospital should be closed and it was that Government through him that commissioned a report by Comhairle na nOspidéal which recommended the abolition of surgical services at the hospital.

In view of this how could any voter put their trust in anybody other than Fianna Fáil to safeguard the hospital's future? The times we live in do not allow us the luxury of a protest vote for the sake of protest and the people of Roscommon should vote Fianna Fáil now to secure the future of the hospital because they may not get a second chance.
The present Minister of State at the Department of Health is quoted in another article under the heading: Leyden “Totally Committed to Hospital”. It reads:
Only Fianna Fáil can guarantee retention and future development of County Hospital and a vote for Terry Leyden is a vote for our County Hospital and its future.
These quotes are direct quotes from the Roscommon Herald, dated 13 February 1987, in the last general election campaign.

We know the result of the general election campaign: Fianna Fáil came into office. However, when the Western Health Board were notified of their allocation for 1987 the amount allocated for expenditure in this current year was over £8 million short of what would be needed to maintain the services at 1986 levels. In the figures that subsequently had to be prepared by the CEO of the Western Health Board the budget for the county hospital at Roscommon was cut from £3.2 million in 1986 to £1.9 million for the current year of 1987. A plan drawn up for the hospital based on an allocation which had almost halved the previous year's allocation had the most drastic content in terms of cutbacks. The first proposal from the Western Health Board was that the county hospital would be completely cancelled as a county hospital and would be reduced to the status of a district hospital. That was amended somewhat by a later proposal coming shortly after that which said that the county hospital would be reduced from its present complement of 137 to 152 beds to 49 surgical/medical acute beds and that the remaining beds be allocated to psychiatric patients and to long-term geriatric patients. The nursing staff was to be reduced to 30 and in short the hospital was being given a token reprieve and would be put out of its agony by complete shut down in a year at the very most.

Naturally this was not acceptable to the people and most of the public representatives in the county rejected the proposal. The hospital action committee organised a very effective groundswell against the proposal throughout the county and throughout the catchment area. They were in parts of County Galway and County Longford, too, where the catchment area reaches.

The consultants and the staff and the action committee all being realistic people had a number of meetings with the local health care committee, which is a subsidiary body set up by Roscommon County Council. In the subsequent discussions a proposal was formulated which recognised the reduced expenditure and set a realistic bottom line of 100 medical/surgical beds for the hospital. This was an effective 50 per cent reduction in the care level in both of those areas. It was agreed that the remaining beds to be released under this arrangement should be part of the psychiatric admissions unit proposed for the hospital on the closure of the admissions unit at St. Patrick's Hospital in Castlerea.

These figures were arrived at on the basis that if any reasonable fair play was to apply in the allocation of £121.420 million that is the total allocation for the Western Health Board including the GMS service in 1987 — Roscommon Hospital would have to get a figure of at least £2.4 million to staff and keep up and run the 100 bed proposal. That was based on the hope of fair play and on the most cursory look at recent past experience. For instance in 1983 when the total health board budget was £103.852 million, Roscommon got £3.5 million. In 1986 when the health board budget was £121.880 million, Roscommon got £3.2 million. That is the relationship between the two figures, if you were to base your thoughts on fair play.

The hospital action committee organised a very effective groundswell for this proposal and against the original proposal throughout the county. The 100 bed proposal was eventually put to the Western Health Board at their meeting in July. It was countered by a proposal from the Department of Health and it would appear that the Minister of State lobbied very strongly for it. His proposal was for a kind of cocktail of 60 surgical/medical beds, ten one day stay beds and 30 psychiatric beds. This counter proposal was put to the Western Health Board meeting at their July meeting and was carried, albeit with the casting vote of the chairperson. One might comment on some of the strange shenanigans that appeared to take place at that meeting but that at least was the result. After this meeting in July intense pressure was put on the staff in the hospital to opt for redundancy or transfer. This pressure described to me by a number of nurses as sheer intimidation worked well as far as the Department of Health appeared to be concerned. The number of nurses on the staff was reduced from 80 to 43 with other reductions among staff in the other grades working there. Significantly the deal on redundancy and transfer was clinched just one week before the following meeting of the health board to be held in Ballinasloe on Monday, 5 October 1987. On the agenda for that meeting was a proposal that the Swinford decision be reversed. That again is the 60/30/10 cocktail I talked about — that that cocktail be replaced with just a simple proposal that there be 100 medical/surgical beds for the hospital. That was proposed by local Councillor, Mr. Des Bruen and may I, in this House, congratulate him for his initiative and indeed for his courage. He is a Fianna Fáil councillor. He had the imagination, the initiative and the courage to bring forward this proposal. After a long discussion at that health board meeting, sometimes it was very acrimonious, the question was put and the vote resulted in Mr Bruen's 100 bed proposal being carried — 13 for, 11 against and one abstention. That is now health board policy.

I want to refer back to a meeting with the Minister for Health, Dr. Rory O'Hanlon held here in this House on 23 June last. Parties at that meeting were the Minister, the Minister of State and public representatives from the county, TDs, Senators, the councillors and representatives from the hospital action committee. The case for the hospital was fully put to the Minister by a wide range of speakers. He was told that the hospital was the most economical in the region. He was told that the cost per week per occupied bed in the hospital was £671.28 and he was given the following comparisons: cost per week per occupied bed in Merlin Park, Galway £769.29; cost per week per occupied bed in the Regional Hospital in Galway, £862; cost per week per occupied bed at the County Hospital in Castlebar, £734.28 and the cost per week per bed at the Sligo Regional Hospital, £779.83. These comparisons were given to the Minister because 90 per cent of the patients from the catchment area who could not be accepted in Roscommon because of reduction or indeed closure would have to be treated in these institutions.

It was pointed out to the Minister that there was 5,000 admissions to Roscommon Hospital in 1986 and that that kind of figure was on target for 1987. Also pointed out to him was the appalling prospect and the appalling problem, both for patients and relatives, of having to transfer that kind of patient population to alternative hospitals or institutions, an average of 50 miles away. It was pointed out to the Minister that many of the patients receiving treatment in Roscommon were over 65 years of age, which complaints that are common in patients of that age group, respiratory problems, hypertension, fractures etc. It was pointed out that this was a natural corollary of having a population structure in the catchment area where almost 18 per cent of the population are 65 years of age and over. The national average for that age group in the total population of the country is 11 per cent. The Minister's reply was that he accepted the description and the value of the hospital but that it appeared to him that it was a victim of democracy on the Western Health Board, that it appeared that Roscommon could not muster enough support to carry the 100 bed proposal and that was too bad. But the point of view he put forward was that because he believed in democracy on the Health Board he did not intend to interfere with the working of that democracy, even if it meant bad or dangerous decisions were taken by that kind of democracy. That point was made to him. Yes, Roscommon failed to get enough support in Swinford. It did take the casting vote of the chairman to carry the provisional 60 bed proposal. One could not blame the Minister. Roscommon's 100 bed complement proposal failed to get the vote in July in Swinford by the democratic casting of a vote against it by the chairperson. Now democracy on the health board operating on October 5 last at a full general meeting, voted 100 acute beds for Roscommon and thereby cancelled 60 beds, so beloved it would appear of the Minister and his Department.

I have seen a report that the Minister has instructed the CEO of the health board not to accept the 5 October democratic decision. I cannot believe that. It would be a complete and total contradiction of what he said on 23 June last. I want the assurance of the Minister of State on behalf of the Minister here this evening that that is not so. I want his assurance that the stated policy given to us by the Minister on 23 June still stands, that is, his belief in local democracy. It is absolutely urgent that the Minister of State should answer positively now in order that the health board hospital can cancel the offensive Swinford proposal and that the arrangement which ensued from that decision on the instructions of the Minister can be cancelled also.

For the 100 bed democratic decision to be put in place, we need the Minister's say so. It is absolutely essential that he says “yes” or that the Minister of State says “yes” on his behalf here this evening. There is appalling confusion in the hospital at present. Urgent cases are being turned away because there are insufficient beds. Take the case of one very unfortunate woman and we will call her Mrs. H. to protect the people involved. She was referred to the hospital, obviously very ill, on Monday, 2 November. When she arrived, there was no suitable bed for her and she was referred home on medication. However, her condition worsened rapidly at home and she was referred back to the hospital on the evening of 3 November. She had to be kept in casualty from 8.30 p.m. on the evening of 3 November until 1.50 a.m. on the morning of 4 November before she was given a bed and formally admitted to the hospital. That unfortunate woman died two days later leaving her family and many others convinced that she would be alive today had she been admitted on 2 November and had she not had to go through the ordeal of having to wait for over five hours, obviously very seriously ill, in the casualty department of the hospital until a suitable bed became vacant for her. There are other things I would like to say but I will leave them and listen to the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. Leyden) Terry Leyden
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Mr. Leyden)
Speaker.P: I am delighted to get the opportunity to speak to the Seanad on this very important matter. I have taken a very positive role on this issue to ensure that Roscommon County Hospital will be retained in its role as an integral part of the acute care hospital system. As a result, the services provided at Roscommon will continue to be an essential element of the hospital services in the Western Health Board area. The hospital will retain its current complement of consultant staff, who, I am sure, will continue to provide a loyal, dedicated and first class hospital service to the people of Roscommon.

In addition, the hospital will be provided with an acute psychiatric unit which will be the focal point for a modern day psychiatric service in Roscommon. These are the facts of the matter and I am glad to be able to give these assurances to this House. I repeat that Roscommon Hospital is to be retained. It will have in addition an acute psychiatric unit. It will continue in its present role as an acute general hospital and is fully integrated into the wide range of services provided in the Western Health Board area at both hospital and community level.

Following the issue of the allocation to the Western Health Board this year, I know there was considerable debate and discussion as to how the services should be rationalised so that expenditure would be in line with allocations. Ultimately the board took a decision on 6 July 1987 to provide 100 beds at Roscommon. These 100 beds are to be made up of 35 medical beds, 25 surgical beds, and ten day surgical beds, plus a 30 bed acute psychiatric unit. I was fully aware, however, that this decision would result in some reduction in the scale of activity at Roscommon Hospital but not in the effectiveness of the services provided.

MainHeading.P: As a result I was aware that the question of redeploying staff or offering some staff redundancy terms under the package approved by the Government would arise. Consequently, I took the initiative and played a particular role in this issue to ensure that whatever had to be done was done with a maximum degree of humanity and sensitivity. I am happy to be able to say that a satisfactory and acceptable solution emerged in all cases. Also I am delighted to say that I have secured the public commitment to the hospital of all staff remaining in Roscommon. This, of itself, will ensure the future of the hospital and can be regarded as a source of comfort to the patients and all who come in contact with the hospital.

I wish to confirm that the future of Roscommon acute general hospital is now secure and confirmed by my colleague, Deputy O'Hanlon, Minister for Health, and the Secretary of my Department, Mr. Liam Flanagan. The Secretary, Mr. Flanagan, and I were impressed by the public commitment of all the staff to provide a full service when we visited the hospital officially on 24 September 1987. I wish to take this opportunity to appeal to all concerned to support Roscommon County Hospital so that the public can have complete confidence in the knowledge that the hospital will remain and continue to provide a first class service to the public. This will enable the management to plan and provide the necessary resources to support the agreed level of activity. The staff can concentrate on providing a service to the patients without the distraction of worrying about their future employment and the local community can be secure in the knowledge that they have an effective local hospital service. I think the Seanad will agree that this is something to which we should all aspire and it is one to which I am devoting my whole-hearted commitment and support within the Department.

I would like to remind the House that in the services which are being provided we have the services of a first class physician in Dr. Pat McHugh providing a full general medical service. We have the services of Mr. Michael Relihan, the general surgeon, providing a full surgery service. We have an anaesthetist, Dr. Maura Casey; we have a radiologist; we have full casualty and theatre services. We have also full out-patient services, consultancy staffed medical and surgical clinics, orthopaedic, ear, nose and throat, pediatrics, dermatology and other facilities like dental clinics. We have also other community services associated with the hospital and the clinic adjoining it. Those services should be recognised.

I wish to reject the negative approach by some people for their own reasons to publicly downgrade the hospital. I gave a commitment which Senator Connor mentioned and I stand over that commitment to the future of the retention of Roscommon County Hospital as an acute general hospital. I wish to remind the Seanad that we have in the hospital the services of a full time surgeon, a physician, an anaesthetist. We have the services of radiologists. We have 11 non-consultant hospital doctors; we have 43 nurses; we have eight sisters; we have all other back-up staff. We have other services being provided there. I wish to appeal at this stage for the full support of our county hospital and the assurances which have been given are given with the full commitment of the Department. I hope the public will be assured that those services will be there. The guarantee and commitment are there for the county hospital and remain there. I hope public representatives will act responsibly in ensuring that public confidence is secured in the county hospital in Roscommon.
The Seanad adjourned at 5 p.m. until 2.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 25 November 1987.
